reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is a Wizard?

This game is all about skill. It is PURE skill. Said skill is demonstrated in real time via mechanical execution, muscle-memory, level-headedness, reaction, anticipation, situational awareness, adaptation, and mind games. It is the purest test of all-around personal, gaming capability. All of these are intricately tied to and driven by the first listed skill form: mechanical execution. Mechanical execution is the core of the game. It enables the test of level-headedness. Mechanical execution, and all other forms of skill, suffers when under pressure. Keeping your cool is necessary to not fumble spells. It is necessary to successfully cast the correct spell.

It tests a player’s personal muscle-memory potential. A large number of spells are possible. Because each of these must be cast extremely quickly at any given moment, muscle memory is formed and tested by repeated mechanical execution.

It perfectly tests reaction in both parts; reflexive speed and quick decision making. Using the correct spell in reaction to an opponent’s action is necessary for survival. Being able to successfully cast a given spell in reaction to an opponent, before said opponent can pull off an action or combo, requires fast and correct, mechanical execution. Warding !SES before an opponent can detonate SES is a perfect and common example of this in practice.

Extending from reaction is situational awareness and anticipation. The possession of such ability comes from ascending beyond deliberately typing spells to effortlessly casting spells. This is a challenge on muscle-memory. When a player is focusing on how to cast a spell, that player cannot anticipate actions and that player has limited capability to “see” the battlefield; the mind is too consumed with casting that spell. However, when enough of the proper actions and reactions are truly mastered, a player can begin to anticipate things and think beyond casting a spell. One can innately know the next spell to cast in a combo, know the proper counter to it, know if the opponent will be able to defend in time, and, not only know what the opponent would potentially do to stop the player, but which action(s) that opponent is most likely to do in the current situation.

But, if muscle memory is needed to attain situational awareness, and by extension, anticipation, why not remove it so that players can immediately partake of and enjoy the “end-game”? The answer is that anticipation is a test of muscle memory, not that muscle-memory is a needless gate into anticipation.

So, how does anticipation test muscle memory? This is where adaptation and mind games come in. Certain common combos become expected. Rather quickly, a player realizes that SES is generally followed by back-pedaling with FFF. This is anticipation. By anticipating the FFF one might summon an !E to nullify that FFF, thereby preventing the detonation of the mines. However, that player may also anticipate said reaction and shoot QRS to detonate the mines. One may realize that player understands this concept and drops an EDF instead, overwriting some of the mines, blocking FFF if that player uses it, and blocking some of the ice if the player uses that. There are a handful of “correct” decisions that can be made in reaction to such a combo and there are a handful of ways to adapt that combo. All of these further test muscle memory and mechanical execution.

Players must predict what each other will do and set up chains of attacks and tactics to throw an opponent off. This is the key. This is everything. This is the true test. By fighting an opponent that is trying to throw you off, you must be capable of casting the correct spells with which to defend against that player’s attacks. You must have more spells locked in your muscle memory to be able to throw your opponent off. Each opponent that takes you down offers you a lesson. You learn a new potential combo or attack chain. You use that knowledge against others and prevail until someone devises a tactic that negates it. And.. then you learn again.

This is what makes a wizard better than another wizard. The better wizard knows more spells. The better wizard can cast those spells faster. The better wizard knows which spells are best for each situation and knows how other wizards will react to those spells in those situations. The better wizard can probe the weaker wizard, feeling out that wizard’s style and skill level; a tendency toward an element, a tendency toward a specific spell or tactic. The better wizard can exploit that style, turning it into a weakness. When the same is done to the better wizard, the better wizard adapts and turns it back on the weaker wizard, throwing him off guard, thus putting him on the defensive. Mind games.

Wizarding is the truest test of pure skill and intelligence. I love it. Thank you so much devs.

Early Access Review

Highly competitive fast pased action game, probably one of the best arena team games on steam along with dota 2.
It plays almost like a fighting game during duel mode because its 1v1 bo3, using mix ups, corner pressure, combos to punish your opponent, reads and defense with rock paper scissors, but the difference is everyone is in the same boat, with access to the same spells, the only difference is knowledge, speed, counters, damage combos and position and there is always someone better than you to verse. The skill ceiling is quite high you need to practice your muscle memory, and spell rotations in training mode, and to constantly think about how to punish your opponent for their mistakes, its very challenging and really fun.

The other mode is warfare which is basically the meat and potatoes of the game, its the team portion of the game and is played 4v4, the objective is to stop the opponents from respawning and kill them one last time, this is done either by reducing the tokens to 0 by capping spawn points, killing enemies and letting the tokens drain by maintaining spawn points, or to capture all the spawns on the map in your teams favor and killing them, because without it they cannot respawn. There are a few different maps, maps with 3 spawns, or maps with 4 spawns, as well as some with teleporters to move around the different sections of the map. Its rather simple, but like all good team games, there is lots of depths due to how you position around the map, and how you control your opponents. You and your teammates can come up with different ways to win, maybe by holding more spawn points, and pushing the enemy into an area of the map where they are trapped, or maybe you want to use your healing spells to push through and try to capture somewhere else, by rotating differently everytime, it can get quite complex, but it is really fun and i cant wait to see how the game shapes up in the future, with more maps, more magicks to use (which cost meter by killing people, capturing spawns and slowly going up over time by itsself).

There are different robes to customise your wizard with, and some are quite cool, and the rest rather funny, its Magicka after all. You can also team kill your teammates, which can be funny, and there is a time and place for it. Though it does help with the competitive nature of the game, because you have to be careful and to judge if its best to use particular spells or not.

The community is awesome for the most part, everyone of all levels if you stick around will become invested, and will get to know people who are serious about getting better at the game, or having fun (though this can be seen as negative because the community is so small with a lack of much growth at the moment)

I totally recommend this game to everybody. When you play this game I`m pretty sure that there`s no stoping you.
This game is a 99% skill based game, wherein the remaining 1% goes to luck. You need to use your skills in order to win.
The 99% also breaks down to several categories like speed, survivality, offensive, strategy and of course muscle memory.

Speed: The one who is faster has an advantage over the enemy.

Survivality: If utilized well, you will be the first one to enter the battle and the last one to leave.

reviewText:
Think of this game as mini-DOTA with capture points. No lanes, no gold, no leveling, no warding, no mana, just eight elements that you can combine to your heart's desire in 5-10 minute games. There are also Magicks, which are similar to skills in other MOBAs, powerful spells that spice up the gameplay a lot. Usually because that one noob cast Meteor Shower on your entire team by accident.

This game is not pay-to-win. You can purchase in-game money with real cash and XP boosters but that's it. Your character gains XP after each game and when you level up, you gain Mastery Points, which you can invest in unlocking new robes, staves, weapons and Magicks. You can also buy variants of everything but Magicks in the store, as well as consumable Magick scrolls. Robes and staves each have an affinity. These boost your wizard's affinity towards an element(Or Health/Speed), while removing the same amount from its opposite. You could be an extremely effective Lightning wizard but fully charged 3xEarth spells take off half your health, making skill the deciding factor.

To beat your opponents you need to kill them. That seems easy and button-mashy but it isn't. You will die a lot when you first play this game. It's incredibly challenging and rewarding once you get the hang of it. A few basic things to know is when to ward(personal shield, self-cast shield and any two elements) and when to switch wards, when to fight and when to retreat, what spells to be using and at what distance you should be fighting at.

If you've played the original Magicka, it's a bit less chaotic and far more fair, with a couple of other changes. You can only queue three elements at once, Steam and Ice no longer appear as their own element in the queue when combining Fire/Water and Cold/Water respectively, Lightning now has priority over Life/Death, Self-Cast now doubles as AOE, sword enchanting is gone, and casting with no elements uses your weapon instead of pushing air.

And for ♥♥♥♥s sake, don't use a life ward.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Quick Review-
Have you ever wanted to mix elements together to invent new spells, want to run around and shoot fire balls or lightning at your friends/enemies? Is your life lacking that special “magical” element? Well Magicka: Wizard Wars has a solution to your dilemma!
Magicka: Wizard Wars is a MOBA where you can mix different elements to create different spells, in addition to a level system once that game is finish, gives the game a fun sense of progress, in addition to leveling you have different types of gear you can equip to boost different stats on your mage.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  Oh no! Do you see all those mages with red names? They need to die, like now! What are you waiting for, melt their faces! Look, stories really aren’t applicable in MOBA; this game is tailored for PvP, that’s what MOBA’s do.

Game Play: There are 8 different types of spells that can be mixed to create different types of moves. You can mix 3 healing/regeneration spells and then cast it to heal yourself, or mix together a shield and earth to create rock armor. In addition to the magic mixing, you also have 4 action skills that slowly recharge as you cast spells.
There is also a nice leveling system in place, so that win or loss you get experience towards the next level, and get rewards for accomplishing various matches.

Achievements: No steam achievements for this game (At this time – The game is Early Access Game)

Price: Magicka: Wizard Wars is a free to Play game. There are things in the game you can purchase or grind to get better advantages… or simply aesthetics. That is where the game gets their money, so do keep that in mind.

Conclusion: I’ve played a number of MOBA’s, many of them are good, but they take a lot of time to get the hang of, and there is always that part of the community that is cut throat about skill level. I’m sure I’ll come back to this game later and play more, but at this point I just wanted to get the general idea for the game.
It ran smooth, was very easy to pick up and play with, has a bit of a unique learning curve… all in all, I enjoyed the game, and do intend to play more.

This is an update from my previous review:

This game has exceptional core mechanics. Recent updates have fixed some complaints, but not all.

Matchmaking doesn't seem to take any concept of player skill into account. I'm rather bad at the game, and I keep getting matched up against teams that dramatically outclass my abilities. It's certainly not an easy thing to keep track of, but because of the amazing depth of the mechanics, skill-based matchmaking system is a must.

I previously complained about a lack of a PvE area, and the tutorial area provides the essential safe place to practice. However, it does little to prepare you for the insane rigor required to properly think on your feet and react and defend from enemy spells. I hope that eventually, this mode will evolve to include enemy wizard AI so that you can practice your defense and countering skills.

In general, the lack of skill-based matchmaking still makes this game very difficult to get into, but the tutorial level makes things much better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally, Magicka has a versus mode... which apparently ended up being even better because it's F2P.

Magicka: Wizard Wars is a F2P game based around the combat system from the original Magicka. The concept is simple - You have several elements you mix in order to create a powerful spell, whether its purpose is to heal, burn, or crush enemies. Alongside with three other players and some weak meelee-only imps, you are sent to kill out another team of four players. After winning a match, you are given experience points and 'crowns' (Sounds familiar to me, hehehe) you then use to get different equipment to crush your foes more easily. And that's about it for the concept. Fast, simple, fun.

One of the main advantages of this game is it's F2P aspect. It really is truly F2P - you can't make yourself stronger by purchasing stuff for real money. That's because when you buy a robe, ring, trinket or stave, you exchange some strenght of one of your elements to increase the power of another one, or alternatively increase your speed in exchange for less health and vice versa. The elements make up pairs - you can mix several types of equipment to decrease several of your powers just slightly, or get a full equipment set to make yourself a master of one element, rendering the other one in the 'balance pair' useless. So not having any equipment beyond the default one is also a very valid strategy.

Of course, the game requires you to reach a certain level before you can buy items with more drastic effects, while allowing you to buy them immidiately for real money. But this is also slightly countered by the 'daily chest' function - once per day, you can open a chest to get a random bonus, ranging from a little bit of coins or a crystal (more on that later) to a very valuable high-level robe. The chance of a valuable item drop is increased by winning Wizard Warfare matches that day.

The game itself then has two gamemodes: Duel and Wizard Warfare, both equally fun yet completely different. Wizard Warfare is a team-based gamemode where two teams of four players try to destroy eachother. There are also spawn points around, allowing you and your team members plus imps to respawn if they get a bit unlucky.  Both teams then have 100 tickets to start with, losing one anytime a imp or a player respawns and, if the enemy controls more spawnpoints than you, dissipating over time. Your target is to capture all points or have the enemy run out of respawn tickets so you can eliminate them forever. It is very important to cooperate and lay waste to both the enemy and their imps, as these usually eat up most of the tickets, while also trying to keep the spawnpoints secure and your teammates healthy.

The Duel mode, however, is played in four - two players fight in an arena, while the other two spectate, with all players trying to score six kills to win. The winner of each fight stays in the arena, and is given another player to fight, while the defeated is sent to spectate until is chosen to fight again. This gamemode is, however, kind of secondary - it's a good practice, you'll learn to counter and outcounter your enemies, but it's usually less populated and matches may end up being stalemate-ish.


The fight itself is based around spells and magicks. You may combine up to three elements to create a spell, and rest assured these always make sense - three flame tokens make your stave a flamethrower, three earth tokens make it throw a giant rock, when combining these two makes you shoot a fireball. But you can also use spells on yourself, for example, combining one shield tokens with two arcane tokens makes you immune to arcane damage. There are many possibilities, and I am quite sure you'll find your own playstyle soon.

Magicks are then much more powerful than spells. In the bottom of your screen is slowly charging up your magick  mana , letting you use your four magicks from different catagories. Using your first magick catagory only eats up 25% of your mana , the second one uses up 50% and so on. The magicks are also progressively more powerful as they require more mana, using the fourth one properly will usually result in at least one guaranteed wizard kill. It also means you may use the first magick four time in a row if you have enough mana - very useful in the case of Haste, for example. There are several magicks within these four catagories - you may unlock them from bundles from the store (real money payment) or get more of them trough crafting them from crystals. You will need more crystals for better magick catagories, which drop every time you reach a new level, or from daily crates.

Last but not least, your wizard is not only a magick user, but can also use meelee to eliminate foes. These are much more variable than other equipment options, and even though the damage and attack intervals don't change too much, each weapon has a different attack type - cleave, slash, freeze, dash, charge... fun stuff.

All this is packed into the now classical Magicka look with autentic feeling - the nameless and faceless wizard, the narrator with his lovable voice and sarcastic lines, puns in item descriptions, references to other games and movies, gore-filled deaths and the relaxing music in the backround all make the game feel even better. All this for free.

Actually, I don't know what are you doing here anymore. The game is free - so I hereby recommend it and am ordering you to play it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GAMEPLAY : 8/10

Magicka: Wizard Wars is an innovative MOBA game where it takes spellcasting to a whole new level. This game has a combination of 240 spells totals.

The tutorials is poorly done that explains only few basic mechanics.

There is a total of 8 spells in your arsenal. Ranging from rock,water,ice,fire,shield,death,heal & lighthing. You also have 4 special actives which you can use if you fill up the meter with each attacks you perform. You can choose different special actives too given that you have the requirement crystal to unlock it ( leveling up gives you different type of crystal or you can buy them ). Different spells counters different spells too so you need to think strategically. Basically everybody is Invoker from Dota.

In a 4 vs 4 modes,there is a total of 3 base you can captured and each opposing teams have 95 respawn tokens. If a player dies or one of the team have more towers than the opposing team,it will slowly deminish their respawn tokens. Once it is finished,the game is over. Oh and also each of the base have imps that spawn to protect it.

BEWARE !!! This game has friendly-fire so if a trolls come to your team,it basically gg for you.

You can also 1 vs 1 with other players too. It basically a test to see how good you are at spells combinations.

Every match you finish gives a random amount of gold depending on your score and if you win or lose. From there you can purchase different staves,robes,secondary weapon,trinkets & rings. You can also purchase real cash items which gives you different stats & looks. If you thinking this make the game pay 2 wins,you're wrong. It true that certain items gives you benefit but it also give you certain disadvantages. Your character have 8 elemental resistance attributes. Let say if you purchase a robes that gives you +20 rocks elemental resistance but -20 water elemental resistance. You most likely will receive more damage from water spells but at the same times you receive less damage from rock spells.

GRAPHICS : 7/10

While the game doesn't look spectacular,it pretty acceptable for the most part.

The visual fidelity and the artstyle is great as well as some of the spells particles.

Character models is not bad either.

AUDIO : 7/10

Sound effects for different spells is pretty well done.

There is not many in-game music but it ok for me considering it a MOBA games.

LONG-LASTING APPEAL : 5/10

The game really lack some content. There isn't much modes and leveling up is not rewarding at all. The only good things is that you can experiment different spells with each match you plays. Apart from that the game is pretty much barebone. Hopefully they can add more during their final release.

FINAL VERDICT : 6.8/10

Would i recommend to people who likes MOBA games ? Not really,the game has a steep learning curve and if you can't managed to counter different spells,you most likely will get owned. Maybe people who master using Invoker in Dota shouldn't have problem with this game.

I only recommend to those who are old fan of the Magicka games and people who really like some challenge and spellcasting fanatic.

New players could try this game but don't expect any in-game guides to help you a lot.

GRADE : D ( Not Bad )

But-

This combat and fast-paced action of the whole game is amazing (This could be described as a Dota 2-Magicka.).

The magicks system was nerfed (This was to make the game fair), but the whole range of different advantages and disadvantages to look out for and be ready for is the thing that really makes this game intense.

Altogether score: 8/10

unlike in the original magicka magicks are now casted using a button press, as opposed to putting the elements in the way that you where supposed to,
also you may remember you had five element slots, in this you have three,
also your elements do not mix anymore unlike the first magicka where if you summoned say fire and water you got steam, in this game you can still cast steam but your elements only mix when you cast and not when you summon them like in the first one therefore making spell casting less efficent and more annoying.

Hey buddy, have you heard of Magicka: Wizard Wars? No? Then i shall tell you what it is, so hold on to your manliness because this is a story to move the last hair that your head will be able to hold.

Heck, how should i even begin? It's Magicka, a game where you can play around with 8 elements and combine them at your own will, and wow has it come good, it's surprisingly good!
Needle-less to say, you will make lots of mistakes and panic... lots, but do not worry! it's everyone! Everyone gets seriously stressed when they do even a really tiny mistake, it can f*ck up everything!
New content comes out often so if you get bored of it you just won't if you give it another try.

This game is early access, yes, that's why i hate so much about it. Come out already! be a good game! The european servers in this are absolute poo, i can't swear on this steam review thingy or it will filter it and i want to do a beautiful text, there is people fighting against their region and going out to other regions, MASSIVELLY ruining the fun, seriously, you will see lots of high ping mages in this.

Ok, so out of technical to physical. You may already know what the hell this game has to offer so let's go to the point:
You can no longer combine 6, or was it 8? elements together, they have been nerfed to just only 3 elements.
The graphics are noticeably better with more three-dimensional 3D and more elemental elements. It's quite pretty actually.
The combat is something that has also amazed me, you could already fight in original Magicka bla bla bla, but nobody has friends on the internet, AMIRITE? I READ IT SO IT MUST BE TRUE.
We have been introduced to the 1v1 duel mode not so long ago, but it has been removed temporalially(?) just so we can come back to the sweet old 4v4.

No, this game is not a moba, but it feels like one, i would say it's an improvement over a moba, you will also need to use your brain or glue your fingers on 3 certain elements to make sure you use the right combination of butt kicking elements.
The elements have lots of variations between them, yes, ice and water will make frozen water that will send out spikes, and no you cannot combine water with fire, steam will come out of it, so the game is pretty balanced and i find that awesome.
You can  combine everything with everything and heck, even make it strategically!
You can combine heal+water to heal and extinguish a teammate that is on fire!
But it will also make them wet so they will be more vulnerable to lightning and also, won't be able to use lightning or else they'll shock themselves. Oh yes you can use fire and healing to take care of that but hey, he's going to burn!

There is already a great variation of weapons and robes, each of them giving you a different attribute advantage and what is the best thing? YOU ARE NOT PAYING MONEY FOR IT! IN-GAME CURRENCY ONLY!
Oh and also sometimes gems will drop and with those gems you can make unique Magicks that are holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ extremely powerful.
And annoying, can't forget annoying (stupid teleporters)

The downsides? Yes of course if you ask for them i can deliver them.
As i have already mentioned, servers suck, matchmaking takes quite a while in europe but it compensates because you CAN search for a match during training, which i find more games should do this.
Annoying water-spammers, if someone sprays you with water you will be rendered useless because, wow, you will be splashing, and guess what? you are wet! they will just spray you over to a wall and suffocate you with ice spikes.
Other than that i do not think the game has anything that let me down really, only really bad networking, but guess what! they are hiring! so if you are a network engineer please help us and go over at paradox north, you will save a country.

+You can damage enemies as well as teammates

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNow in open beta, Magicka: Wizard Wars is a fun, chaotic and sometimes amusing multiplayer game. There are only 2 modes and 2 maps (not counting duel mode's arena) so far, but the gameplay is sufficient to keep you entertained for at least a good few hours. There are eight elements that you can combine to create a variety of spells, from laser beams and ice projectiles to earth barriers and healing mines. In addition to that you have four magicks, which come in four tiers, which become available gradually as you fill the respective bar by killing enemies and completing objectives. These abilities can, if used right, become game-changers, especially the tier 4 abilities which deal immense damage over a large area. It can seem overwhelming at first, but the training mode provides a good outlet for experimentation and learning combinations. There are 2 modes at the moment: the 4v4 control-point style Warfare where you capture spawn points and the 1v1 Duel mode. Outside of matches, you can unlock or buy cosmetic items and alternate types of magicks. It's incredibly grindy, as some cosmetics require high levels while magicks require several crystals of various elements. These are given randomly as you level up. However, I haven't felt frustrated yet as the default magicks are sufficiently useful and fun to use, and the eight elements which are the core of the gameplay are all available right off the bat. I haven't seen enough of the unlockable magicks in action to determine if they're unbalanced, but the tier 4 Thunderstorm magick seemed slightly better than the default Meteor Shower in one of the matches I played, as unlike the latter there are no marks on the ground to indicate where the lightning will strike and it seems to have a 100% chance of striking you. Apart from that, what I've seems pretty balanced, with skill, reflexes and knowledge of combinations and counters determining victory or defeat rather than getting new gear and magicks. Some of the gear do provide benefits, but similar to TF2 they are balanced out by having negative attributes as well. Matches don't last for too long, usually up to ten minutes and sometimes even ending in a minute, making it suitable for brief gaming sessions while still feeling long enough to satisfy. If more maps and modes are added and the grind is reduced, this has the potential turn into a free-to-play gem. In it's current state, it's a good game that is definitely worth trying out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is easily one of the best multiplayer experiences you can have. The spellcasting is great, allowing for devastating combos that are easy to remember. The number of elements you can combine has been reduced from five to three, but this only serves to streamline the combat and speed it up slightly.

Players can switch between roles on the fly, as they become necessary. Long range fights? Start hurling rocks at the enemy wizards! They are now running away? Switch to a pure beam of death and stay on target. Are your friends injured? Heal 'em up with a quick blast from a healing beam and they'll be back in the fight in no time.

Friendly fire is still very much 'a thing' and it is for the better. You can use your teammates to arc your deadly lightning towards the enemy, or just blast a boulder straight through them if they're in the way. Whenever you're about to complain after dying in a friendly Meteor Storm, just think back to all the times you cast that magick when two of your friends were within its area of effect. What goes around comes around, they say.

As you deal damage to your enemies and heal allies, you'll slowly charge your magicks. You'll get Haste, which simply boosts your speed, but what you're really after are the last two: Grim Reaper and Meteor Storm. The former summons a 'friendly' Grim Reaper, who will proceed to chase down an enemy player, and deal massive damage to him. Or if there are no enemies nearby, he'll just slice you. He's gotta make a living, you know! The latter, as the name implies, causes about two dozen meteors to rain from the sky and absolutely murder everything in a given area. In case anyone survives a direct blast, they'll burn to a crisp from the flames the meteors cover them in.

If you've found yourself bored with other multiplayer only titles and are now aching for something different and new, Magicka: Wizard Wars is definitely for you. And if you secretly hate your friends and wish to melt their faces off, you're in luck, as this game allows you to do that too!

Overall, I have really enjoyed my first couple of hours on this game and can see myself playing long term. I would like to see some new game modes and new items to keep the game interesting and diverse, but other than that, excellent F2P and worth a download.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is easily one of the best multiplayer experiences you can have. The spellcasting is great, allowing for devastating combos that are easy to remember. The number of elements you can combine has been reduced from five to three, but this only serves to streamline the combat and speed it up slightly.

Players can switch between roles on the fly, as they become necessary. Long range fights? Start hurling rocks at the enemy wizards! They are now running away? Switch to a pure beam of death and stay on target. Are your friends injured? Heal 'em up with a quick blast from a healing beam and they'll be back in the fight in no time.

Friendly fire is still very much 'a thing' and it is for the better. You can use your teammates to arc your deadly lightning towards the enemy, or just blast a boulder straight through them if they're in the way. Whenever you're about to complain after dying in a friendly Meteor Storm, just think back to all the times you cast that magick when two of your friends were within its area of effect. What goes around comes around, they say.

As you deal damage to your enemies and heal allies, you'll slowly charge your magicks. You'll get Haste, which simply boosts your speed, but what you're really after are the last two: Grim Reaper and Meteor Storm. The former summons a 'friendly' Grim Reaper, who will proceed to chase down an enemy player, and deal massive damage to him. Or if there are no enemies nearby, he'll just slice you. He's gotta make a living, you know! The latter, as the name implies, causes about two dozen meteors to rain from the sky and absolutely murder everything in a given area. In case anyone survives a direct blast, they'll burn to a crisp from the flames the meteors cover them in.

If you've found yourself bored with other multiplayer only titles and are now aching for something different and new, Magicka: Wizard Wars is definitely for you. And if you secretly hate your friends and wish to melt their faces off, you're in luck, as this game allows you to do that too!

Early Access Review

This game is SO good. It really makes you feel like a mage of awesome strength. There's no picking a few spells out of a list and having to use them the whole game, you just build them on the go from basic elements. And it allows you to cast them in numerous ways, with direction, or on yourself to produce an AoE effect, or provide a shield from 1 or 2 elements at a time.

Sometimes your fingers get a little confused on the keys, and cause you to cast spells you didn't want to cast, but I feel like that's kind of appropriate for a mage in the middle of a crazy battle. However, I would really like them to add a key that allows you to clear all current elements you have floating. I feel like that's something a powerful wizard should be able to do in an instant.

The synergies of all the magics and status effects are really good, but provided with a bit more depth, could put this game on the map a little bit more.

Really, though, this game is RAD. It could use some TLC, most definitely, especially in the form of more maps (as it currently only boasts 2), and another game mode or two would be nice (Capture the Imp, anyone?). Even with only two maps, it's still super fun and engaging, has never gotten old or stale, and if you're good enough at the controls, you can go toe to toe with well-geared-out mages, even as a beginner, so it is certainly NOT pay-to-win" at all. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: this product is not in a finished state, but is still a representation of the definite core game. The game is still in its Early Access “alpha” stages, Changes to the game may happen post this review.

Wizards wizards wizards, Paradox interactive is back with a new installment in the Magicka series, now in a more MOBA-Like format. The base game is still the same, you have 8 element at your disposal (water, life, shield, ice, lightning, arcane, stone and fire), to combine and cast as you please. But this time around you can only combine 3 instead of five of the elements, and you have 4 additional spells that you can cast using the 1,2,3,4 keys, these spells can be switched out as the player sees fit, before you enter queue and the battle.

The game itself is classic moba action; there are 2 teams with 4 players on each team. Each team has a certain amount of spawn points which goes down as players die and respawn. There are 2 ways of winning the game, one of the goals of the game is to capture the 3 spawn areas to prevent the enemy from spawning in, and when the enemies’ team has no players left on the field the game is over. The other way to win is to basically kill the enemy until you have depleted their spawn points, once that is done kill the remaining enemy to win the game. At the end of the game you are awarded Exp. And gold according to how well you have performed during the match. (Kills, captures, etc.) Gold can be used to purchase different weapons, staves and robes, different staves and robes have both buffs and debuffs. You are also awarded magic stones to purchase new magic skills with.

The game starts out with a short tutorial, to get the player familiar with the basics of the game, moving around, using spells etc. then the game begins you are free to queue up start an actual match. During match queue the first flaw will present itself, currently there is no ELO system implemented in the game, so you might be paired up against an enemy who has full gear and has played and gotten more familiar with the game then a newbie. There is supposed to be an ELO system implemented later on but is not currently in the game. You start fenced in with your teammates until the game is underway, you can either go up or down. The map can easily be compared to League of Legends Dominion mode, in both gameplay and map layout though smaller in comparison. The game time can vary from 1:30 min’s to 20 min. depends on how skilled your teammates are and how skilled the enemy is. This is where the game may differ from other mobas on the market; the game time can be supper quick, giving you the opportunity to get some quick games in, in your past time. Though it can be very frustrating sitting in a 5 min queue to join in, and when you finally get in, you just get steamrolled. The game itself can be hard to learn, takes time to truly master, though it seems like most of the better players use the same set of skills. That definitely can come off as spamming the cheapest and the best skill over and over again, which may turn off newer players from the playing game. Takes time to truly get familiar with the game.

It pays of to be quick on the keyboard, because this game is purely skill based. Healing is definitely an ability that is essential for the player’s survival, though there are tricks that make you heal almost all health over a very short period. This in my case comes off as a bit broken, as you almost can heal off all damage thrown at you. Also certain attacks seam very cheap to use, and just down right spammy. This has been one of my main issues with, my time with the game. just knock someone over  and throw an arcane-lightning-cloud over someone and they take quite the damage. Spamming rocks is also something that newbies might encounter but there are ways to counter that. There is plenty of room to outmaneuver your enemy with utility skills such as shield, speed, teleport and revive. Been playing a couple of games that involved a guy reviving teammates, over and over even though their respawn points had ran out, dragging the game out, this adds to the layer of play’s the player can make.

That being said besides that the gameplay doesn’t seem to have the same amount of depth as other mobas out there. There is room for regulating how powerful the spells are according to your gear. But that’s about it, no buying items as the game progress, no getting stronger during the match, you are as strong as you are, everybody is on equal grounds unless or would be, due to the lack of elo system. That makes the game seem dull the longer it drags out, and when you just get steamrolled, it makes you feel so underpowered compared to other more skilled players.

Overall the game is fun and quick, takes some time to get into and master. Not too accessible for new players, definitely to people who is unfamiliar with the gameplay from the previous titles. Gameplay sometimes come off a bit chaotic, and more skilled players seem to use the same cheap attacks over and over again. Lack of elo system is a definite turn off, possibility of newbies to square off against other newbies would be ideal for this type of game. All being said, this feels like a Casual Moba-like experience, and a very good one at that. The game needs tweaking and balancing here and there, very big room for improvements though. The game isn’t finished yet but still in a very playable state, But would still wait till it turns F2P later on.
6,5 / 10

This is NOT a full review - it only details one area that sadly frustrates me enough to not want to play.

If you have multiple monitors, this game will punish you for alt-tabbing. It will throw the game into your non-primaries, hiding 50% of the game, possibly including the settings area (as it did for me) which means you can't change to windowed mode - you're basically locked out of that monitor(s). All you can do in response is go to the task manager to quit the program & try again. Woe to you if you forget mid-game that it does that.

Playing a fast-paced click-to-move in windowed mode is frustrating. I could click out & lose my spell, or windows minimize to desktop, etc.

If I can't tab out quickly to change a song, audio book, or even do some actual work while waiting in a lobby, then this game just isn't for me. If you don't have that need for alt-tabbing, go ahead & get this.
